hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a very small child, but he was a very strong child in his youth; there was no one his equal on these islands from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau, in being both small and very brave. His father was Kauluakaha‘i, from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinu‘u. His mother was Pōka‘ī. His father was a great chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was also of the godly side.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_commentary:
The passage introduces Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a figure of interest in Hawaiian literature and history, highlighting his unique characteristic of being small in stature but exceptionally strong and brave in his youth. The description underscores the cultural value placed on physical prowess and courage, traits that were highly regarded in ancient Hawaiian society, particularly among ali‘i (chiefs) and warriors.

Linguistically, the passage is rich in traditional Hawaiian narrative structures and vocabulary. The use of ʻuʻuku (small) and ikaika (strong) to describe Nāmakaokapāo‘o juxtaposes contrasting attributes, emphasizing his remarkable nature. The phrase "ʻaʻohe ona lua" (there was no one his equal) is a common idiom in Hawaiian storytelling, used to signify someone's exceptional abilities or characteristics.

The mention of Nāmakaokapāo‘o's parents, Kauluakahaʻi and Pōkaʻī, and their association with specific geographical locations (Kahikipapaialewa in Kahikinuʻu), embeds the narrative within a historical and cultural context. The detail that Kauluakahaʻi was an aliʻi nui (great chief) and of the "ʻaoʻao akua" (godly side) indicates his high status and possibly divine or semi-divine lineage, which was crucial in ancient Hawaiian society for determining rank, authority, and legitimacy.

The geographical references, spanning from Hawaiʻi to Niʻihau, frame Nāmakaokapāo‘o's reputation within a broad territorial context, suggesting his renown extended across the islands. The specific locations associated with his father, such as Kahikipapaialewa, may be linked to known historical or mythological places, though their exact significance would depend on further contextual or historical research.

Historically, this passage may reflect the blending of genealogical and mythological narratives characteristic of Hawaiian oral traditions. The reference to Nāmakaokapāo‘o's divine lineage and his father's status as a great chief indicates the narrative's engagement with themes of ancestry, power, and legitimacy, which were central to Hawaiian chiefly societies.

The structure of the passage, with its balanced presentation of Nāmakaokapāo‘o's physical attributes and his genealogical background, reflects traditional Hawaiian storytelling techniques that often intertwine personal characteristics with genealogical and geographical information to establish a character's significance and contextualize their actions within a larger narrative.

The mention of Nāmakaokapāo‘o's parents, Kauluakahaʻi and Pōkaʻī, and their association with specific geographical locations (Kahikipapaialewa in Kahikinuʻu), embeds the narrative within a historical and cultural context. The detail that Kauluakahaʻi was an aliʻi nui (great chief) and of the "ʻaoʻao akua" (godly side) indicates his high status and possibly divine or semi-divine lineage, which was crucial in ancient Hawaiian society for determining rank, authority, and legitimacy.

The geographical references, spanning from Hawaiʻi to Niʻihau, frame Nāmakaokapāo‘o's reputation within a broad territorial context, suggesting his renown extended across the islands. The specific locations associated with his father, such as Kahikipapaialewa, may be linked to known historical or mythological places, though their exact significance would depend on further contextual or historical research.

Historically, this passage may reflect the blending of genealogical and mythological narratives characteristic of Hawaiian oral traditions. The reference to Nāmakaokapāo‘o's divine lineage and his father's status as a great chief indicates the narrative's engagement with themes of ancestry, power, and legitimacy, which were central to Hawaiian chiefly societies.

The structure of the passage, with its balanced presentation of Nāmakaokapāo‘o's physical attributes and his genealogical background, reflects traditional Hawaiian storytelling techniques that often intertwine personal characteristics with genealogical and geographical information to establish a character's significance and contextualize their actions within a larger narrative.</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
